articles.headline: How Tim Walz’s Time in the House Paved the Way for His Ascent
articles.snippet: The congressional voting record of the Democrat nominee for vice president shows his liberal streak, but with a deference to a conservative district’s needs.
articles.abstract: The congressional voting record of the Democrat nominee for vice president shows his liberal streak, but with a deference to a conservative district’s needs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Representative Tim Walz was traveling across his conservative, rural district in 2014, holding town halls across southern Minnesota, when a voter confronted him with a prickly question about his support for the Affordable Care Act.
articles.byline: By Catie Edmondson and Luke Broadwater

articles.headline: The Barber Will See You Now. The World Will See You Next.
articles.snippet: At the Olympic Village, cuts, styles and manicures are free. The benefits, the athletes say, are priceless.
articles.abstract: At the Olympic Village, cuts, styles and manicures are free. The benefits, the athletes say, are priceless.
articles.lead_paragraph: They are one of the most popular teams at the Olympics. Their hand-eye coordination is off the charts. Their uniforms? Head-to-toe black and très chic.

articles.headline: Swifties in Vienna Cry, Commiserate and Try to Shake It Off
articles.snippet: Taylor Swift fans from around the world grappled with disappointment and fear after a terrorism plot derailed the Vienna dates of the Eras Tour.
articles.abstract: Taylor Swift fans from around the world grappled with disappointment and fear after a terrorism plot derailed the Vienna dates of the Eras Tour.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just as she was boarding her flight at Boston Logan International Airport headed for a Taylor Swift concert in Vienna, Mary DePetris excitedly checked the online fan group, Swiftie Nation.

articles.headline: How China Built Tech Prowess: Chemistry Classes and Research Labs
articles.snippet: Stressing science education, China is outpacing other countries in research fields like battery chemistry, crucial to its lead in electric vehicles.
articles.abstract: Stressing science education, China is outpacing other countries in research fields like battery chemistry, crucial to its lead in electric vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: China’s domination of electric cars, which is threatening to start a trade war, was born decades ago in university laboratories in Texas, when researchers discovered how to make batteries with minerals that were abundant and cheap.

articles.headline: Ferguson 10 Years Later: How Protests Gave Way to Politics and Policy
articles.snippet: The shooting death of Michael Brown created a political incubator of emerging local leaders, some of whom are finding themselves in the corridors of power.
articles.abstract: The shooting death of Michael Brown created a political incubator of emerging local leaders, some of whom are finding themselves in the corridors of power.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Michael Brown Jr., an unarmed Black teenager, was fatally shot in 2014 by a white police officer and his body left in the street under the August sun, the small St. Louis suburb of Ferguson roiled and plunged into crisis.

articles.headline: Wall Street on Edge After a Week of Wild Swings
articles.snippet: Investors have a factor to consider beyond the pace of inflation: Could the next sign of sputtering economic growth send stocks into a tailspin?
articles.abstract: Investors have a factor to consider beyond the pace of inflation: Could the next sign of sputtering economic growth send stocks into a tailspin?
articles.lead_paragraph: After a wild week in the markets that rekindled fears about the strength of the U.S. economy, investors are wondering what comes next.
articles.byline: By Joe Rennison and Danielle Kaye

articles.headline: As Ukraine Pushes Deeper Into Russia, Moscow Sends Reinforcements
articles.snippet: The Ukrainian police said they were evacuating people, perhaps in anticipation of a retaliatory strike, but the goal of the military operation on Russian territory remained unclear.
articles.abstract: The Ukrainian police said they were evacuating people, perhaps in anticipation of a retaliatory strike, but the goal of the military operation on Russian territory remained unclear.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ukrainian forces pressed deeper into Russia on Friday, trying to capitalize on their surprise cross-border offensive, as Moscow moved quickly to shore up its defenses against the largest assault on Russian soil since the war began.

articles.headline: Can This Woman Save the United States?
articles.lead_paragraph: Susan Gibbs needs to find a new parking spot, fast. And not just any parking spot will do.

articles.headline: The Paris Bridge of Olympic Joy and Its Violent Past
articles.snippet: The Pont du Carrousel, gathering place of joyous crowds, has come to symbolize a season of magic. It was not always so.
articles.abstract: The Pont du Carrousel, gathering place of joyous crowds, has come to symbolize a season of magic. It was not always so.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the Olympic Games have made of Paris a midsummer night’s dream, perhaps the Pont du Carrousel has been its heart, a dimly lit bridge over glittering water, a merry-go-round of incarnations as the weeks have passed.

articles.headline: Trump’s Tax Plan Could Add to Debt Burden. Harris’s Plan Tracks Biden’s.
articles.snippet: The former president’s proposals to cut taxes would lose far more revenue than his plans to raise tariffs. The vice president has not released specifics.
articles.abstract: The former president’s proposals to cut taxes would lose far more revenue than his plans to raise tariffs. The vice president has not released specifics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump keeps adding new tax cuts to his list of campaign promises, and their projected costs keep piling up.

articles.headline: Tim Walz Was a Clear Eyes, Full Hearts Kind of Coach
articles.snippet: “The guy was never negative,” another coach said. “That’s what we loved about him. Everything was a positive.”
articles.abstract: “The guy was never negative,” another coach said. “That’s what we loved about him. Everything was a positive.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Minneapolis’s Metrodome hummed, its sidelines jammed on a fall Friday night. The Mankato West Scarlets, who had started the 1999 high school football season with a miserable record of 2-4, had improbably swaggered into a state championship game. Now, less than three minutes stood between them and a title.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder and Eli Tan
